item.title: Bud Light Boycott Sparks Big U.S. Profit Drop for AB InBev
item.description: The brewing giant lost market share after the Dylan Mulvaney debacle, but it says consumers remain favorable toward Bud Light.

item.title: German Exports Remain Sluggish as Trade Surplus Grows
item.description: German exports rose just 0.1% on month in June, though the country’s trade balance was boosted by even weaker imports, suggesting increasingly squeezed demand.

item.title: Nintendo's Profit Rose on 'The Legend of Zelda' Game, Mario Film Successes
item.description: The videogame maker maintained its forecasts for Switch consoles and software sales as well as for fiscal-year earnings.

item.title: Bond Markets Remain in Wait-And-See Mode
item.description: Government bond markets are in wait-and-see mode, Generali Investments said, adding that while inflation rates should continue to decline moderately, the resilient U.S. economic data and 10-year yields well below the policy rate argue against a noticeable decline in yields in the short term.

item.title: BMW Warns on 2023 Pretax Earnings
item.description: BMW guided for a significant decrease in group earnings before tax for 2023, but said it now expects solid solid growth in deliveries to customers worldwide this year.

item.title: Adidas Cuts Forecast Loss as China Leads Rebound
item.description: Adidas was back in profit in the second quarter, helped by a recovery in China and easing of inventories, and forecast a narrower operating loss for the year of €450 million.

item.title: AB InBev Delivers Solid 2Q With Absence of Negatives
item.description: AB InBev delivered a solid enough second quarter, with organic Ebitda and headline EPS above expectations and its Ebitda guidance range maintained—so the absence of any incremental negatives should be enough to drive shares higher, Citi said.

item.title: Infineon Outlook on Track After In-Line Third Quarter
item.description: Infineon backed its guidance for the year after posting third-quarter revenue and a segment result that met forecasts, despite mixed demand.

item.title: ING Outperforms as Revenue Jumps
item.description: ING reported a jump in net profit for the second quarter to €2.2 billion as revenue rose 23%, with income growth in both retail and wholesale banking.

item.title: AB InBev Earnings Beat Hopes Despite Drop in US Volumes
item.description: Anheuser-Busch InBev reported normalized earnings of $4.9 billion, slightly above forecast, as organic revenue grew 7.2%, and despite a steep drop in North America volumes.

item.title: Lufthansa Boosted by Strong Demand But Costs Weigh
item.description: Lufthansa’s second-quarter adjusted earnings almost tripled to €1.1 billion on a 17% rise in revenue, but its shares fell sharply, with Citi highlighting rising costs.

item.title: Société Générale Profit Tops Hopes But Revenue Disappoints
item.description: Société Générale swung to a second-quarter net profit from a year earlier but saw its revenue fall on lower net interest margin in France and a less conducive global banking environment.

item.title: Zalando Lifts Adjusted EBIT Guidance Range
item.description: Zalando said its adjusted earnings rose to €149 million in the second quarter and lifted the lower end of its guidance range for the year, but cautioned that revenue and gross merchandise volume would likely be in the lower half of forecast ranges.

item.title: The Dallas Museum of Art Picks a Winner
item.description: The museum selects the Madrid firm of Nieto Sobejano Arquitectos for a makeover of its 1984 Edward Larrabee Barnes building.

item.title: How Primark Built a Thriving Business Without Selling Online
item.description: E-commerce is booming, but Primark is increasing its revenue by focusing on retail stores. WSJ’s Trefor Moss explains how Primark has gained a foothold in the U.S. fashion industry by pushing customers to shop in-store.

item.title: Meta's Ray-Ban Smart Glasses Fail to Catch On
item.description: The company plans the release of the second generation as less than 10% of the devices purchased are used monthly, an internal company document shows.

item.title: PG&E scrapped a program to clear trees alongside power lines that was aimed at cutting wildfire risk and will rely more heavily on new power-line settings to reduce the hazard.
item.description: PG&E scrapped a program to clear trees alongside power lines that was aimed at cutting wildfire risk and will rely more heavily on new power-line settings to reduce the hazard.

item.title: The SEC said some Wall Street stockbrokers must do more to ensure their services aren't being used to launder dirty money.
item.description: The SEC said some Wall Street stockbrokers must do more to ensure their services aren’t being used to launder dirty money.

item.title: Binance was supposed to leave China behind when the country made cryptocurrency trading illegal in 2021, but almost two years later, users traded $90 billion of cryptocurrency-related assets there in a single month, according to internal figures viewed by The Wall Street Journal and current and former employees.
item.description: Binance was supposed to leave China behind when the country made cryptocurrency trading illegal in 2021, but almost two years later, users traded $90 billion of cryptocurrency-related assets there in a single month, according to internal figures viewed by The Wall Street Journal and current and former employees.

item.title: U.S. Capitol Police searched Senate office buildings on Capitol Hill in response to a report of an active shooter, which officials later said was a false alarm.
item.description: U.S. Capitol Police searched Senate office buildings on Capitol Hill in response to a report of an active shooter, which officials later said was a false alarm.
